title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct identification
descriptions: The response does not correctly identify what each point symbol on the map represents.
The response correctly identifies that each point symbol on the map represents one million people.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

Two points are earned for TWO correct identifications
descriptions: The response does not correctly identify any one of the following topographic features shown on the map.
The response correctly identifies ONE of the following topographic features shown on the map.
The response correctly identifies TWO of the following topographic features shown on the map.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

Two points are earned for TWO correct descriptions
descriptions: The answer does not correctly describe any one of the following ways that topography affects the spatial pattern of population distribution shown on the map.
The response correctly describes ONE of the following ways that topography affects the spatial pattern of population distribution shown on the map.
The response correctly describes TWO of the following ways that topography affects the spatial pattern of population distribution shown on the map.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and/or examples, and to score the response.

One point is earned for a correct description
descriptions:
The response does not provide the following description of how the availability of natural resources may affect population distribution.

· In areas with sparse natural resources (for example, harsh climate, lack of suitable soil for agriculture, lack of fresh water), population is likely to be more sparsely distributed.

The response provides the following description of how the availability of natural resources may affect population distribution.

· In areas with sparse natural resources (for example, harsh climate, lack of suitable soil for agriculture, lack of fresh water), population is likely to be more sparsely distributed.
